fields.descriptive_line: Set of large-scale casts, coloured and gilded, of different ceiling elements from a 15th-century house in the Harat al-Rum (possibly the Qasr Rumi), Cairo. St Maurice collection.
fields.physical_description: Set of large-scale casts, coloured and gilded, of different ceiling elements from a Mamluk house: a pendentive cornice formed of two angled curved sections decorated with Arabic calligraphy, punctuated by muqarnas (stalactite) niches (extant); two "stalactite brackets" (disposed); and "parts of a ceiling". The extant pieces to which these parts must refer are: a flat square section decorated with a star and cross pattern; and a large section of a coffered ceiling, with three beams. These casts seem to have been made from the same pinkish locally-available Egyptian building plaster which is used to make the other casts from the St Maurice collection.

fields.uncertainty: Plaster casts were installed in the maison arabe built for St Maurice  between 1872 and 1879 by the

fields.public_access_description:
These large and coloured plaster casts of architectural elements probably come from a Mamluk house called the Qasr Rumi, now demolished, which once stood near the Bab Zuwayla in Cairo. They once decorated the lavish rooms of the ‘maison arabe’ of the French aristocrat, the  Comte Gaston de St Maurice (1831-1905), which was built for him between 1872  and 1879. 

St Maurice lived in Cairo for twenty years, serving as equerry to the Khedive  (Ottoman governor) of Egypt. During that period, he accumulated a large collection  of historic objects from Islamic Egypt, dating especially from the 14th-16th  centuries but also including some 19th-century objects. The V&A acquired  about 200 objects from St Maurice collection in 1884.
fields.bibliography:
<u>List of Objects in the Art Division, South Kensington Museum acquired during the Year 1884.</u> London: Eyre and Spottiswoode, 1885. p. 98
Mercedes Volait, <u>Maisons de France au Caire: le remploi de grans décors mamelouks et ottomans dans une architecture moderne</u> (Cairo: Institut Français d’Archéologie Orientales, 2012)
Photographs of interiors of the St Maurice house which show ceilings resembling these casts are on pp. 61, 63, 70, 88, 110, 111 (Grand Salon); 64, 65 (modern Chancellery of French Embassy in Cairo); 78, 145 (Salon des Cachemires); 258-71 (ceilings in the modern house).
Anne-Christine Daskalakis Mathews, <u>Le porche mamlouk</u> (Paris: Musée du Louvre, Somogy, 2012)
The plaster casts probably come from the same house in the Harat al-Rum as the 'porche mamelouk' in the Musée des Arts Décoratifs in Paris (also from the St Maurice collection), now installed in the Islamic Galleries at the Louvre.
fields.history_note:
Registered description: Plaster casts. Pendentive cornice, two stalactite brackets, and parts of a ceiling, partly coloured and gilt, from a house in the Hárat-er-Rúm, at Cairo. The original Saracenic, 15th century.

Bought from the collection of Gaston de St Maurice (1831-1905). Plaster casts numbered 1020-1884 to 1046-1884 were bought for a  total of £60.

Originally 1030 to 1030i were acquired. Parts A, B, D, H and I were written off (destroyed) in 1934. See RP/33/2518.

These large plaster casts come from a house in the Harat al-Rum quarter in Cairo, possibly called the Qasr Rumi. They probably come from the same house as a Mamluk stone porch, also in the St Maurice collection and subsequently sold to the Musée des Arts Décoratifs in Paris; in 2012 this was reconstructed and installed in the Islamic Galleries at the Louvre. A number of drawings of the porch while it was still in situ in Cairo, drawn by the French architect Jules Bourgoin (1838-1908) while he was in Cairo between 1880 and 1884, are labelled 'Kasr Rumy' (Qasr Rumi, 'Palace of the Christian') and 'GSM' for 'Gaston de St Maurice'.

According to Daskalakis Mathews 2012 (p.16) Harat al-Rum was a quarter in the city of Cairo located next to the Bab Zuwayla. It was the principal quarter of the Greek Orthodox community and residence of its patriarch. In the 19th century, Copts also lived here as well as some Muslims. Qasr Rumi may have been the main house of the quarter. It was likely destroyed during urban redevelopments in the late 19th century.

<u>Collecting context:
</u>
The V&A holds approximately 200 objects from the collection of the Comte Gaston de St Maurice (1831-1905). St Maurice was a French aristocrat working in  Cairo for some 20 years as equerry to the Khedive (Ottoman governor) of Egypt.  During that period, St Maurice accumulated a large collection of historic objects  from Islamic Egypt, dating especially from the 14th-16th centuries but also  including some 19th-century objects. His tastes ranged widely and his collection  included works of art from Syria, Iran, India, East Asia, as well as Europe. These  objects were installed, some of them as furnishings, in the maison arabe built for  him between 1872 and 1879 by the French architect Ambroise Baudry (1838- 1906), who designed several houses for prominent French ex-patriates in Egypt.  Part of the decoration of St Maurice’s house included plaster casts taken from a  variety of historic buildings across Cairo, especially those built during the reign of  Sultan Qa’itbay (r.1468-96). 

St Maurice exhibited his collection at the 1878 Paris Exposition, where it was seen  and its quality commented on by curators from the South Kensington Museum  (now the V&A). After the exhibition, St Maurice’s collection remained in Paris, on  deposit in the Musée des Arts Décoratifs. Due to the increasing political instability  in Egypt, culminating with the British occupation (in 1882), St Maurice tried to sell  his collection to the South Kensington Museum. The price was considered too  high, but part of the collection was received on loan in 1883, the remainder staying  in Paris at the Musée des Arts Décoratifs. Eventually in 1884, the loaned objects  from St Maurice were bought by South Kensington. Stanley Lane-Poole (1854- 1931), Arabist and external advisor to South Kensington on ‘Saracenic art’,  considered this collection to be “of the greatest value and rarity”.
fields.historical_context_note: The pendent cornice (1030-1884) was as copied in the Museum and given the number Repro.1884-820. This reproduction was recorded as being on loan to the Royal Scottish Museum according to nominal file (12/12/21).
